o: Authentication scheme allowing a user to log in with a single ID/password to any of several related, yet independent, software systems.
System that creates, maintains, and manages identity information for principals and provides authentication services (e.g. Okta, Azure AD).
The application (e.g. Salesforce, Slack) that wants to verify the user's identity and trusts the IdP to do it.
Trust relationship between distinct security domains (IdP and SP) typically established by exchanging metadata/certificates.
XML-based standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between an IdP and an SP.
XML packet containing statements about a subject (User), issued by the IdP. Trusted by SP because of the digital signature.
The Assertion signature is verified using the IdP's Public Key (stored in metadata) and conditions (Expiry, Audience) are met.
Attack on SAML. Attacker moves the signed part of XML to a different location and injects malicious content (Admin claim) that is processed but not verified.
Identity layer built on top of OAuth 2.0. Uses JSON (JWT) instead of XML. Modern standard for SSO.
JWT containing claims about the authenticated user (sub, name, email). Intended for the Client (App) to consume.
Access Token authorizes access to an API (Resource). ID Token proves identity to the Client (App).
URL (/.well-known/openid-configuration) where IdP publishes its config (Issuers, Key endpoints, Supported scopes). Auto-configures clients.
JSON Web Key Set. URL where IdP publishes its PUBLIC keys used to sign tokens. Clients verify signatures using these.
Subject Identifier. Unique ID for the user within the Issuer. Stable and never changes for the same user.
Issuer. URL of the entity that created the token (The IdP). Client must match this against expected config.
Audience. Identifies the intended recipient of the token (Client ID). App must reject tokens not meant for it.
Random string sent in Auth Request and returned in ID Token. Prevents Replay Attacks in Implicit/Hybrid flows.
Safest OAuth/OIDC flow. App gets a temporary Code, exchanges it back-channel (Server-to-Server) for Tokens. Tokens never exposed in URL.
Extension to Code Flow. Prevents Code Interception attacks on Public Clients (Mobile/SPA) by requiring a dynamic code_verifier.
Opaque value sent by client to maintain state between request and callback. Crucial for CSRF protection in SSO.
If IdP redirects to any URL in 'redirect_uri' param without validation, attacker can steal Auth Codes/Tokens.
Standard API (JSON/REST) for Provisioning and Deprovisioning users. 'Create user in generic App when created in AD'.
Creating the user account in the App (SP) ON THE FLY the first time they log in via SSO. Usage driven.
User starts at IdP, clicks App icon. Risk: Vulnerable to CSRF/Replay/Injection on SP side because SP didn't solicit the response.
User visits App, App redirects to IdP. App tracks 'State'. More secure due to request/response correlation.
Logging out from IdP triggers logout from ALL active sessions in connected Apps. Hard to implement reliably.
After initial login, KDC issues TGT. User presents TGT to get Service Tickets for specific apps without re-entering password.
Attacker compromises the KDC (krbtgt account) key. Can mint TGTs for ANY user (Fake Admin) with infinite validity.
Translating IdP attributes (e.g. 'departmentNumber') to App attributes (e.g. 'Role'). Done at IdP or SP.
When a user belongs to too many groups (e.g. 1000+), the Kerberos/SAML token becomes too large for HTTP Headers -> Login Fails.
Strict/Lax modes can block IdP cookies in iframes (Silent Renew) or POST redirects. Needs 'None; Secure'.
If SP doesn't verify the signature, attacker can forge a token claiming they are Admin. CRITICAL flaw.
JWT Attack. Attacker sets alg: 'none' and removes signature. Poorly coded libraries might accept unsigned token.
Attacker manipulates 'kid' (Key ID) header in JWT to point to a key THEY control (or user/db lookup injection).
Form of SSO where a massive IdP (Google) handles auth for 3rd party apps. Reduces password fatigue.
If App allows linking 'Login with Google' to existing account without verifying ownership, attacker can takeover account.
XML file exchanged between IdP and SP containing EntityIDs, Endpoints, and Public Certs. Basis of trust.
Process of replacing expiring Signing Keys. IdP publishes new key in metadata. SP must update trust store to avoid outage.
Ensures redirections happen over HTTPS. Prevents stripping SSL during the IdP <-> SP hop.
Loading IdP login page in an invisible iframe to trick user into typing password. Prevent with X-Frame-Options: DENY.
Browser automatically sends current Windows Credentials (Kerberos/NTLM) to Intranet sites. Seamless SSO.
Proxy sits in front of Legacy App. Proxy handles OIDC/SAML, then injects headers (USER_ID) to App. App trusts Proxy.
Step where user enters email (user@corp.com) and System routes them to the correct IdP (corp.com ADFS).
Combine SSO with FIDO2/WebAuthn. Even if user visits fake IdP, FIDO fails. SSO token never issued.
Delegation: App acts ON BEHALF of User (Target sees 'App acting for User'). Impersonation: App BECOMES User (Target sees 'User').
Client authenticates to Token Endpoint by signing a JWT with its Private Key. Better than shared Client Secret.
IdP calls a web hook on the SP server-side to notify of logout. More reliable than relying on User Browser (Front-channel).
IdP loads hidden iframes in User Browser to trigger logout on various SPs. Depends on browser allowing 3rd party cookies.
Condition in Assertion specifying WHO can consume it. If App receives token meant for different App, it MUST reject.
Timestamp after which Assertion is expired. Mitigates Replay Attacks (Window of opportunity is small).
Every time RT is used, a NEW RT is issued. The old one is invalidated. Detects theft (Reuse of old RT triggers alarm).
Token is bound to the Client's Private Key. If stolen, thief cannot use it because they can't sign the DPoP proof.
App trusts IdP A. IdP A trusts IdP B. User from B can log in to App via A. (e.g. B2B Guest Access).
Legacy, weak hashing (MD4/MD5), susceptible to Relay Attacks, no mutual auth. Replaced by Kerberos.
Unique identifier for a service instance in Kerberos (HTTP/web.corp.com). User gets ticket for specific SPN.
Regularly changing the shared secret used by App to authenticate to IdP. Prevents long-term compromise.
Parameter requesting specific permissions (e.g. 'openid email profile'). Consent screen shows these to user.
UI shown by IdP asking user 'Do you want to allow App X to access your Email?'. Mandatory for 3rd party apps.
Acceptable because the trust is established via Out-Of-Band metadata exchange. CA chain is not strictly required.
Deprecated in OAuth 2.1. Returned tokens in URL fragment (history leakage). Replaced by Code Flow + PKCE.
Encrypted JWT. Content is hidden from the client/intermediaries. Only the holder of the Private Decryption Key can read claims.
A JWT that is both Signed (JWS) AND Encrypted (JWE). Provides both Integrity/Non-repudiation and Confidentiality.
OIDC Protected Resource. App sends Access Token to this endpoint to get JSON details about the user (email, name).
Returns both an Authorization Code AND Tokens (ID/Access) to the frontend. Allows immediate UI update while backend exchanges code.
IdP gives a DIFFERENT 'sub' ID to each App for the SAME user. Prevents apps from colluding to track user activity (Privacy).
Specifies the maximum allowable time (seconds) since the user last authenticated. If exceeded, IdP MUST re-authenticate user.
Tells IdP to check for existing session WITHOUT displaying any UI. If not logged in, return error. Used for silent frames.
Forces IdP to prompt user for credentials, even if they already have an active session (Re-auth).
App sends user's email to IdP. IdP pre-fills the email field on login page. UX improvement.
String in token indicating HOW strong the auth was (e.g. 'urn:loa:2'). App checks if it meets requirements.
JSON array in token listing specific methods used (e.g. ['pwd', 'otp', 'face']). gives granular details.
Parameter used to remember where the user was (Deep Link) before redirection to IdP. Restored after login.
Sending SAML Assertion inside an HTML Form POST (via Javascript auto-submit). Standard way to deliver tokens (too big for URL).
IdP sends a tiny 'Artifact' (Reference) to SP via Browser. SP calls IdP Back-channel to fetch the real Assertion. More component interaction.
Identifier for user that stays the SAME across sessions. Used for account linking.
Temporary identifier valid only for the current session. Enhances privacy/anonymity.
Central 'Hub' IdP connects to many SPs ('Spokes'). SPs trust the Hub. Hub trusts other IdPs. Simplifies trust management.
Global WiFi federation for education. Uses Radius hierarchy. User authenticates to Home Uni IdP while at Visiting Uni.
Discovery Service page where user selects their Home Institution (IdP) from a list before being redirected.
Time difference between IdP and SP servers. If too large, tokens appear expired/not-yet-valid. Validators allow 'Leeway' (e.g. 5 mins).
Token is not valid until this time. Prevents tokens issued in the 'future' (due to clock skew) from being used instantly if check is strict.
Processing the same token twice should have same effect, BUT Replay Protection usually blocks the second attempt.
SP stores used 'jti' or 'nonce' values. If a token arrives with a known value, it's a Replay Attack -> Block.
Claim in ID Token. Hash of the Authorization Code. Validates that the Code used matches the ID Token issued.
OIDC claim specifying which Client ID triggered the token issuance. Crucial when ID Token is given to another party.
Legacy OAuth flow where App asks User for Username/Password directly. ANTI-PATTERN. Breaks MFA. Deprecated.
Managing the lifecycle of identities and access rights. Who has access to what? Is it still needed?
Periodic process where managers/owners confirm if users still need their current access rights. Removes stale access.
Collecting user data (City, Job) in small chunks over multiple logins instead of a huge form at signup. Reduces friction.
W3C standard for digital credentials (Driver License) held in User Wallet. user presents proofs to Verifier. Decentralized.
URL scheme (did:example:123) that resolves to a DID Document containing Public Keys. No central registrar (unlike DNS).
Proving a claim (e.g. 'Over 18') without revealing the underlying data (e.g. 'Date of Birth'). Privacy preserving.
Sharing only specific fields of a credential (e.g. Name) while hiding others (Address) from the Verifier.
JWTs are stateless/self-contained. Server doesn't track them. To revoke, you must wait for expiry or build a Blacklist (state).
Opaque string (Random GUID) pointing to data on server. Client must call Introspection Endpoint to validate. Revocable instantly.
RFC 7662. OAuth 2.0 endpoint where Resource Server sends the token to IdP to ask 'Is this active?' and 'What's in it?'.
Attacker creates a malicious App named 'Office Upgrade' and tricks user into granting 'Read Email' permission via OAuth Consent.
Some high-privilege scopes (e.g. Directory.Read.All) require an Administrator to grant consent for the entire org.
Permissions granted to the App itself (Service Principal) running as a daemon. No signed-in user. Dangerous if leaked.
App acts on behalf of signed-in user. Access is limited to the intersection of User's rights AND App's scopes.
Cloud Admin account excluded from MFA/Conditional Access/Federation. Used only if IdP is down/misconfigured.
Conditional Access rule blocking protocols (POP3/IMAP/SMTP) that don't support MFA. Reduce Password Spray surface.
Syncing hashes of On-prem AD passwords to Azure AD. Users log in to Cloud directly. Resilient to On-Prem outages.
Azure AD validates password by sending it to On-Prem Agent. Password never stored in Cloud. Reliance on On-Prem availability.
Feature allowing domain-joined machines to log in to Azure AD automatically (via Kerberos ticket to AZUREADSSOACC) on Intranet.
Proxy configuration blocking users from logging into PERSONAL/OTHER corporate tenants (e.g. Gmail) on Corp Network.
Setting 'active: false' instead of deleting user record. Preserves history/audit logs.
Sending multiple Create/Update requests in a single HTTP POST. Improves performance for large syncs.
Discovery (.well-known) and JWKS endpoints MUST support CORS (allow *) so browser-based SPs (SPAs) can fetch config/keys.
S256 (SHA-256) is secure. Plain sends the code_verifier as is, which is visible to interceptors. Always use S256.
Never embed Client Secret in Mobile Apps. It can be extracted (Decompilation). Mobile Apps are 'Public Clients' (Use PKCE instead).
Deep linking mechanism (iOS/Android) that proves app ownership of a domain. Prevents malicious apps from intercepting Auth Callbacks.
Use SFSafariViewController (System Browser). It shares cookies with Safari (SSO works) and prevents App from stealing password.
Architecture where a backend service acts as a confidential client, handles tokens, and issues Session Cookies to the SPA. Secure.
Prefix ensuring cookie is set with Secure=true, Path=/, and NO Domain attribute. Prevents subdomain overwriting/injection.
Gateway receives Opaque Token (Reference) from Client, exchanges it for JWT (Value) sending to Microservices. Leaks no PII to client.
Instant revocation is hard. If JWT is stolen, it's valid until expiry. Cannot 'Log out' a specific token easily.
Service A receives user token, calls IdP to exchange it for a NEW token for Service B. Chain of trust.
Standard protocol for exchanging one token (Subject) for another (Actor/Audience). Supports Masquerading and Delegation.
Parameter in Auth Request specifying WHICH API the token is for. IdP issues token with correct Audience. Prevents 'Audience Confusion'.
Attacker confuses Client into sending Auth Code for Honest IdP to Evil IdP. Prevented by 'iss' in Auth Response.
Requests a Refresh Token. Allows App to access resources even when user is offline/not present.
Forces Consent Screen even if previously granted. Useful when user wants to review permissions or for high-risk scopes.
Client requests specific 'acr_values' (e.g. mfa). IdP challenges user if current session acr is insufficient.
Session extends by X minutes on every activity. Keeps active users logged in. Needs an Absolute Timeout limit.
Hard limit (e.g. 24 hours) where user MUST re-authenticate regardless of activity. Compliance requirement.
Restrict where scripts/styles load from. Prevent XSS/Keyloggers on login page. Use 'form-action' to lock submission target.
Users log in to IdP using FIDO Key/Biometrics. No password sent over wire. High security & High UX.
Authenticator is bound to the device (TouchID). Cannot trigger auth from another device.
Authenticator is portable (YubiKey). Can be plugged into any device to auth.
Long-term assessment of user compromise probability (e.g. Credentials found on Dark Web). Triggers Password Reset.
Real-time assessment of specific login attempt (Impossible Travel, Tor IP). Triggers MFA/Block.
Streaming IdP audt/sign-in logs to Splunk/Sentinel. Correlates Identity events with Endpoint/Network events.
Configure IdP to send ONLY necessary claims (sub, email) to SP. Don't send Phone/Address if not needed.
Changes made in Cloud (Password Reset) are synced back to On-Prem AD. Keeps directories in sync.
Entity that issues tokens (OAuth). Often combined with IdP (Authentication). Determines 'What can user do?'
The API hosting the data. Accepts Access Tokens. Validates signature/expiry/scopes before serving data.
Client authenticates to Token Endpoint using a Client Certificate. Stronger than Client Secret.
IdP signs the Authorization Response (Code/State) as a JWT. Prevents tampering/mix-up attacks in the redirect.
Client creates a JWT, signs it with Private Key, sends it as 'client_assertion'. IdP verifies with Public key.
Extension binding tokens to a Client-held Key. Prevents usage of stolen Access Tokens (Replay).
IdP tracks JTI of used tokens (Assertions). If JTI used again -> Block. Requires state storage.
Should be a high-entropy random string (min 43 chars). Not predictable. Hashed to create code_challenge.
Attacker injects a stolen Auth Code into a victim's session. PKCE prevents this (Code is bound to Verifier).
Scopes that include variable data (e.g. 'transaction:123'). Allows fine-grained authz without scope explosion.
Allowing user to grant SOME requested scopes but deny others (e.g. Allow Profile, Deny Contacts).
Invalidated Privacy Shield. EU Identity data in US Clouds requires SCCs + Supplemental Measures (Encryption).
Cloud infrastructure (Azure Germany) physically/logically isolated to meet strict data residency laws.
Running On-Prem IdP (ADFS) disconnected from Internet. Hard to patch/update. No Cloud SSO.
Redirect for Requests (Small). POST for Responses (Large Assertion). Don't accidentally use GET for Assertions (Size limit/Logging).
OpenID (1.0/2.0) is obsolete, focused on AuthN. OpenID Connect (OIDC) is modern, built on OAuth 2.0.
OAuth 2.0 is for Authorization (Delegated Access). OIDC adds Authentication (Identity Layer/ID Token).
If Client doesn't verify 'nonce' in ID Token matches the one sent in Request, Replay Attacks are possible.
Client generates random State -> Sends to IdP -> IdP returns it. Client MUST verify returned State matches. CSRF defense.
If IdP uses 'startsWith' or regex matching for Redirect URIs, attacker can bypass (e.g. good.com.evil.com).
client_secret_basic (Header), client_secret_post (Body), private_key_jwt (strong). Basic is most common.
User owns their identity (Wallet + DIDs). Not dependent on central IdP (Google/Facebook). User controls sharing.
Used to sign SAML Assertions and JWTs (RS256). Public key used to verify. Trust anchor.
Protocol where Resource Owner controls access to their resources. Requesting Party gets a 'Ticket' and asks Authorization Server for token.
The person/entity wanting access to a resource. Must satisfy policies set by the Resource Owner (Alice mentions Bob).
Opaque string given by Resource Server to Client when access is denied. Client sends Ticket to Auth Server to ask for perm (Claims Gathering).
Decoupled auth flow. User buys on PC, Phone buzzes 'Approve Purchase?'. Authentication happens on a DIFFERENT device (Backchannel).
IdP PUSHES a notification to the user's authenticating device immediately after Client request. Fast UX.
Text displayed on the User's Device (e.g. 'Order #1234') to link the backchannel request to the specific user action. Anti-phishing.
High-security profile for OAuth/OIDC. Mandates mTLS, Detached Signatures, specific algs (PS256/ES256), and removing insecure flows.
Signature is sent in a separate HTTP Header (x-jws-signature) covering the body. Ensures non-repudiation of the payload.
For TVs/Consoles. App shows 'User Code' and URL. User visits URL on Phone, types Code. Device POLLS for token complete.
The URL displayed on the TV (e.g. amazon.com/code) where the user must go to enter the Device Code.
JSON containing 'active': true/false. May include 'scope', 'client_id', 'exp'. Resource Server uses this to validate Reference Tokens.
IdP should limit claims returned to RS (e.g. don't return PII 'address' if RS only needs 'active' status). Least Privilege.
Revoking a Refresh Token (Parent) should automatically revoke all Access Tokens (Children) issued from it.
Standard for sharing security events (e.g. 'IP changed', 'Device non-compliant') between IdP and SP in real-time. Zero Trust enabler.
Sharing risk signals (e.g. 'Account Compromised') to downstream apps to trigger remediation (e.g. terminate sessions).
JWT format used to transmit CAEP/RISC events. Signed by Issuer. Contains event payload.
IdP sends SET directly to SP's endpoint via HTTP POST. Immediate action possible.
SP periodically checks IdP endpoint for new events. Higher latency than Push. Easier for some firewalls.
Specific Shared Signal telling SP 'The IdP Session for this user ended. Please kill your session too.'
Signal that 'User changed password'. SP should revoke tokens issued before this time to force re-auth.
Never trust. Always Verify. SSO is central, but Access Decisions must be Continuous (CAEP) and Context-aware.
Apps should request ONLY the scopes they need (e.g. 'email') and NOT 'Directory.Read.All'. Users should review consent.
Process to get into admin console when SSO is broken. Use a specialized 'on-microsoft.com' account monitoring use heavily.
Deploying IdP infrastructure across multiple Availability Zones/Regions to ensure SSO works even if East Coast is down.
Regular rotation (e.g. 90 days). Old keys kept in JWKS for a grace period to allow validation of lingering tokens.
Header in JWT telling Validator WHICH Public Key in the JWKS to use for signature verification. Essential during rotation.
SHA-1 hash of the X.509 certificate. Alternative way to identify the key used for signing.
Binary equivalent of JWT. Used in IoT/Constrained environments (ACE) where bandwidth/processing is limited.
Radius is UDP, older, basic. Diameter is TCP/SCTP, reliable, supports more attributes. Used in LTE/5G.
Extensible Authentication Protocol using Client and Server Certificates. Highest security for WiFi (No passwords).
Wraps legacy auth (MSCHAPv2 - Password) inside a TLS tunnel. Secure, but relies on User Password (risk of rotation/policy).
Intercepting HTTPS connections triggers Browser Warnings (HSTS failure). Hard to do smoothly on modern OS.
Mini-browser on iOS/Android that pops up when 'No Internet' is detected. Limited capability (No cookies/storage).
Attacker sets up AP with SAME SSID as Corporate WiFi. Users connect, attacker steals credentials (via fake Radius/Portal).
Modern VPNs (Cisco AnyConnect, Palo Alto) act as SPs, redirecting user to IdP (Okta/Azure) for MFA flow.
Windows feature. Device authentication (Machine Cert) establishes tunnel before user logs on. Seamless internal access.
Replacement for VPN. Broker grants access to specific Apps, not the whole Network. Identity + Device Context verified per App.
Google Cloud service that puts a proxy in front of VMs. Authenticates user (SSO) before allowing traffic to SSH/RDP/HTTP.
Libraries MUST configure 'Allowed Algorithms' (e.g. Only RS256). Reject 'None' or 'HS256' (Key Confusion attack).
If Validator fetches cert from x5u URL without checking whitelist, attacker can host their own cert and sign fake tokens.
Cryptographically binds the token to the TLS connection (Client Cert/Exporter). Prevents Token Export/Replay if stolen.
MANDATORY. All endpoints (Token, Authorize, UserInfo) must use TLS. Protects credentials and tokens from wiretapping.
IdP returns tokens by rendering an HTML Form with 'action=redirect_uri' and auto-submitting via JS. Keeps tokens out of URL history.
Default for Implicit Flow. Tokens returned in URL Hash (#access_token=...). Not sent to backend, but visible in Browser History.
Default for Code Flow. Code returned in URL Query (?code=...). Safe because Code is one-time use. Tokens NEVER in Query.
Auth Request parameter limiting how old the authentication can be. 'If user logged in > 10 mins ago, force re-login'.
Client that CANNOT maintain the confidentiality of its credentials (e.g. SPA, Mobile App). Must use PKCE.
Client that CAN maintain a secret (e.g. Web App on Server). Uses Client Secret/Cert to auth to Token Endpoint.
Token valid ONLY for specific Target API (Audience). Preventing 'substitution attacks' where token for App A is used at App B.
One App Instance serves multiple Customers (Tenants). App must validate 'tid' (Tenant ID) claim to segregate data.
Encrypting the SAML Assertion/JWT so only the Intended SP can read it. Privacy protection against intermediaries.
Time window (e.g. 2 mins) allowed by Validator for clock differences. 'nbf' and 'exp' checks include this buffer.
Token contains a REFERENCE to a specialized endpoint to fetch extra claims (e.g. Credit Score) instead of embedding them.
OIDC Session Management. Invisible iframe in App polls IdP iframe to detect 'Login Status Change'. deprecated by modern browsers.
User enters Email first. System checks domain -> Redirects to correct Corp IdP (SSO) OR asks for Password (Local). UX pattern.
Email-based passwordless. User clicks one-time link in email. Proves access to inbox. Phishable if link intercepted.
Standard way to express 'How strong is this auth?' (e.g. 'P1.Cc' = Password + Credential Bound). more granular than ACR.
Strength of Identity Proofing. IAL1: Self-asserted. IAL2: Remote proofing (ID Scan). IAL3: In-person proofing.
Strength of Authentication. AAL1: Password. AAL2: MFA (Software). AAL3: MFA (Hardware/FIPS).
Strength of Assertion. FAL1: Signed Bearer. FAL2: Encrypted. FAL3: Holder-of-Key (bound to channel).
IdP generates a DIFFERENT 'sub' value for each Client. Prevents collusion between Clients to profile users.
IdP sends SAME 'sub' value to all Clients for the same user. Allows easy correlation across apps.
URL found in .well-known config pointing to the JSON Web Key Set. Critical for validating token signatures.
URL to redirect user to for Global Logout. Clears IdP session and may trigger SLO.
URL to send Refresh/Access tokens to request their cancellation. Part of OAuth 2.0 extension.
SHA-256 hash of the code_verifier. Mandatory for secure PKCE.
Link to IdP's Privacy Policy. Displayed to user on Consent Screen.
Using signals like Location, Time, Device Health to decide if Auth should succeed or require Step-up.
UI pattern where IdP remembers previously logged-in accounts (via Cookie) and lets user pick one to sign in again.
Federated: Trusting external IdP (Google). Local: Validating username/password against own Database.
List in metadata (authorization_code, implicit, client_credentials, refresh_token). Tells client what flows are allowed.
List in metadata (code, token, id_token). Defines what can be returned from Authorize Endpoint.
Client request instructing IdP to include 'auth_time' claim in ID Token. Essential for Max_Age validation.
Metadata listing how Clients can authenticate (client_secret_basic, private_key_jwt, etc.).
Tokens in URL are logged in Browser History/Proxy Logs. No client authentication. Prone to Access Token leakage.
Not SSO itself, but in microservices, it helps services find each other. mTLS/Tokens often exchanged automatically via Mesh.
Envoy Proxy runs next to App. Proxy handles Token Validation/mTLS. App assumes traffic is clean. Decouples Auth from Logic.
Using URLs (https://myapp.com/role) as keys in JWT to avoid collision with standard OIDC claims.
Keeping the old Public Key in JWKS for X hours after determining a new Signing Key. Allows in-flight tokens to validate.
Client asks for 'acr_values=urn:mfa'. IdP MUST return a token with 'acr': 'urn:mfa' or Error. Enforces MFA.
Transports SAML messages (AuthnRequest/Response) inside an HTML Form body (Base64 encoded). User browser POSTs it to IdP/SP. Handles large messages.
Transports SAML messages in the URL Query String (Deflate + Base64 + URL Encode). Limited length (URL limits). Used for lightweight requests.
Browser sends a small reference (Artifact) to SP. SP calls IdP directly (Back-channel) to fetch the full assertion. More secure, hides data from browser.
IdP signs the XML Response (or Assertion). Proves the assertion came from the trusted IdP and wasn't tampered with.
Encrypting the XML Assertion contents so only the SP (with private key) can read attributes. Privacy protection.
Parameter sent during SSO request to IdP, returned unchanged. Used by SP to remember where the user was (Deep Linking) before login.
User visits App (SP) -> SP redirects to IdP -> User Logins -> IdP redirects back to SP with Assertion.
User logs into IdP Portal (Okta/Azure) -> Clicks App Icon -> IdP POSTs Assertion to SP. Risky (XSRF/Replay), usually disabled or restricted.
The SP receives an unsolicited assertion. Harder to validate if it matches a request. Can be used to force-login users (Login CSRF).
XML document shared between IdP and SP. Contains Certificates, EntityIDs, and URL Endpoints. Establishes Trust.
Unique identifier (URI) for the IdP or SP (e.g. https://sts.windows.net/uuid/). Must match Metadata.
The unique user identifier in the Assertion (Subject). e.g. 'user@domain.com'. Format can be Email, Persistent, Transient.
Condition in Assertion satisfying 'Who is this for?'. Must match SP's EntityID. SP rejects if audience doesn't match.
Time validity window for usage of the SAML Assertion. Prevents indefinite replay.
SP sends this in AuthnRequest to tell IdP: 'Ignore existing session, force user to re-enter credentials'.
SP asking IdP: 'Log me in only if user is ALREADY logged in. Do not show UI'. Used for silent refresh.
Standard (JSON/REST) for provisioning/deprovisioning users. IdP pushes 'Create User' to App when assigned.
SSO handles Authentication. SCIM handles Lifecycle (Creation, Updates, Deletion). Ensures terminated users are removed from App.
App creates the user account ON THE FLY the first time they SSO in, using attributes from SAML/OIDC token.
Doesn't handle DE-PROVISIONING. If user leaves company, account remains in App (though usually inaccessible without SSO).
Allowing a small time difference (e.g. 3-5 mins) between IdP and SP clocks when validating timestamps.
Protocol where logging out of SP triggers a logout at IdP and potentially ALL other other open SP sessions.
Requires breaking sessions across multiple domains. Often fails due to popup blockers or 3rd party cookie blocking.
IdP loads iframes/images from all SPs in the user's browser to clear their cookies. Fragile.
IdP sends a server-to-server POST to the SPs saying 'Session X is ended'. More reliable, requires SP support.
Equivalent to IsPassive. Checks for session without UI. Returns error if interaction needed.
Forces re-authentication even if user has a session.
Forces the Consent Screen (Allow App to access...) to appear again.
JSON file at /.well-known/openid-configuration. Contains issuer, endpoints, supported scopes/claims. Auto-config for Clients.
URL identifying the IdP (e.g. https://accounts.google.com). Must exactly match the 'iss' claim in the ID Token.
Subject Identifier. Unique ID for the user. Should be stable (doesn't change if email changes).
Privacy feature. IdP generates DIFFERENT 'sub' values for the same user for DIFFERENT Clients. Prevents tracking across apps.
Random string sent in Auth Request and returned in ID Token. Client verifies it to prevent Replay Attacks.

q: OIDC vs SAML for Mobile Apps?
o: OIDC/OAuth is JSON/REST based, mobile friendly. SAML is XML/Heavy, hard to parse on mobile. OIDC preferred.
Mechanism to decide WHICH IdP to send the user to (e.g. user enters email -> system checks domain -> redirects to that Corp IdP).
App trusts Okta. Okta trusts AD. User logs in to AD -> Asserted to Okta -> Asserted to App.
Inviting external users (partners) to your tenant. They authenticate with THEIR credentials (BYOID).
Allowing users to sign in with Consumer identities (Google, Facebook, Apple). Convenience for customer apps.
When a shared computer retains the SSO session of previous user. Next user accesses the previous account automatically.
Force Re-authentication, Short Session Timeouts, Clear Cookies on logout, Private Browsing.
Ticket issued by KDC after initial login. cached on client. Used to request Service Tickets without typing password again.
Ticket presented to a specific Resource (File Server/Web Server) to gain access. Encrypted with Service's key.
Packets contain timestamps to prevent Replay. Clocks must be synced (usually within 5 mins).
Simple and Protected GSS-API Negotiation Mechanism. Wrapper allowing client/server to negotiate auth (Kerberos or NTLM).
Legacy Challenge-Response protocol. Vulnerable to Pass-the-Hash. Used if Kerberos fails.
NTLM hash is essentially the password (equivalent). Kerberos uses tickets and mutual auth.
Browser automatically sends current Windows Identity (Kerberos/NTLM) to Intranet sites. Silent SSO.
File containing the Service Account's secret key (extracted from AD). Allows Linux/Java servers to decyrpt Kerberos tickets.
Ability for Server A to impersonate User to Server B. (Double Hop issue). Unconstrained is risky -> Use Constrained.
Server A gets the User's TGT. If Server A is compromised, attacker can impersonate user to ANY service.
Configuring trust on the Resource (Server B) itself, allowing Server A to delegate. More granular control.
Open source SSO protocol (Yale). Ticket-based. User redirs to CAS -> Login -> CAS redirs to App with Service Ticket -> App validates Ticket.
Open Source SAML implementation. Widely used in Education/Research (InCommon Federation).
Application binds to LDAP server with user creds to verify password. Not true SSO (app sees password), but centralized.
Upgrading a plaintext LDAP connection (389) to encrypted (TLS) before sending credentials.
Microsoft's On-Prem IdP. Turns AD (Kerberos/LDAP) into a Federation Provider (SAML/OIDC).
Tool to sync On-Prem AD users/groups to Azure AD. Enables Hybrid SSO.
Feature allowing domain-joined PCs to silently auth to Azure AD using Kerberos (machine account) without ADFS.
Browsers blocking Third-Party cookies (SameSite=Lax). Breaks 'Silent Iframe' SSO checks (OIDC prompt=none) and some logout flows.
SPA (JavaScript) calling IdP API directly must be allowed via CORS headers on the IdP.
Security extension for OAuth/OIDC Public Clients. Prevents Code Interception attack. Mandatory for Mobile/SPA.
Critical for CSRF protection. Client sends random state, IdP returns it. Client verifies match.
Tokens returned in URL Fragment. leaked in browser history/logs. No refresh tokens. Deprecated for SPAs (Use Code + PKCE).
Returns generic Code and ID Token immediately. Client validates ID Token before exchanging Code. Used for optimization.
OIDC standard API. Client sends Access Token, IdP returns User Profile (claims) as JSON.
Required scope to trigger OIDC. Without it, the request is just plain OAuth 2.0 (Authorization only).
Requests a Refresh Token. Allows app to access API when user is not present.
Identifies the Recipient of the token. App MUST reject token if 'aud' does not match its Client ID.
In OIDC, present if ID Token is issued to a Client different from Audience. (Rare, usually azp=aud).
Protocol (RFC 7662) for Resource Server to ask IdP: 'Is this token valid? and what is the meta-data?'.
Stateless. All info (expiry, user, scope) is inside the signed token. RS validates signature without calling IdP (Save latency).
Pointer to state on IdP. RS must call Introspection to validate. Instant revocation possible.
Client gets Opaque Token (safe). Gateway exchanges it for JWT (Self-contained) before hitting backend services.
SPA doesn't hold tokens. Backend (Proxy) holds tokens in session, issues Secure Cookie to SPA. Best security for SPAs.
Vulnerable to XSS. If attacker injects JS, they can read all LocalStorage. HttpOnly Cookies are safer.
Splitting signature of JWT into HttpOnly cookie, payload in JS-readable. App needs both to work. Mitigates some XSS.
High security profile for OAuth/OIDC. Requires Mutual TLS (MTLS), JARM, and strict crypto usage.

q: Mutual TLS (MTLS) for Sender Constrained Tokens?
o: Binding access token to the Client Certificate. If token stolen, it can't be used without the Client Cert.
Application layer MTLS alternative. Client signs request with private key. Token bound to public key.
Parameter passed to SSO to pre-fill the email field (e.g. from invite link). Improves UX.
Parameter passed to skip HRD page and go directly to specific IdP (e.g. 'Redirect directly to Corp AD').
SP acts as a broker (or uses Auth0/Cognito) to federate multiple IdPs (Google, AD, Okta) into one normalized user database.
Merging a Social Account (Google) with an existing Enterprise Account if emails match (requires verification).
Never link accounts unless Email is verified by the Identity Provider. Otherwise attacker claims 'admin@corp.com' on a weak IdP.
Auth is 'Who are you'. Provisioning is 'Creating the account/roles'. SSO does Auth (and JIT). SCIM does Provisioning.
SSO doesn't tell App 'User Fired'. App session might persist or account stays active. SCIM de-provisioning is solution.

q: Break Glass Account in SSO environment?
o: Must NOT rely on SSO. If SSO is down, Admin needs direct local login (username/password) to fix config.
Attacker steals the IdP's Token Signing Key (Private Key). Can forge ANY SAML assertion for ANY user to ANY app. Catastrophic.
Protect IdP keys (HSM). Rotate keys regularly. Monitor for anomalies in Assertion issuance.
CAS is simpler, ticket based. SAML is XML/Soap based, carries attributes. SAML is industry standard for B2B.
OAuth 2.0 is Authorization (Access delegation). OIDC adds the Identity layer (ID Token) to make it SSO. OAuth alone is not SSO.
ID Token = Proof of Identity (For Client). Access Token = Key to API (For Resource Server).
To ensure it was issued by the trusted IdP and content (user id) wasn't modified by man-in-the-middle.
Endpoint publishing the Public Keys of the IdP. Clients fetch this to verify JWT signatures.
Legacy mechanism where IdPs write a cookie to a shared domain (.example.com) to track which IdP the user previously used.
Protocol (RFC 7033) to discover the OIDC Issuer URL given a user email (e.g. user@gmail.com -> https://accounts.google.com).
If one iframe fails to load (due to AdBlock/Network), that specific SP remains logged in. Inconsistent state.
Requires IdP to sign the Logout Token (similiar to ID Token) so SP knows it's genuine revocation request.
Concept where tokens are bound to the underlying TLS channel or Device key. Stolen tokens are useless elsewhere.
Framework for sharing security events (RISC/CAEP) between independent providers (e.g. Google tells Slack 'Account Compromised').
The OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework core specification.
Automated process where a Client Software registers itself with the IdP (via API) to get a Client ID/Secret. Used in Open Banking.
Signed JWT provided by a Trusted Directory (e.g. Open Banking Authority) attesting to the Client's legitimacy during Dynamic Registration.
Regularly changing the Client Secret. Apps must support multiple active secrets during transition to avoid downtime.
If a used Refresh Token is presented AGAIN, the Authorization Server MUST assume theft and REVOKE the entire chain.
Keep it short (e.g. 1 hour). Reduces window of opportunity if stolen. Use Refresh Tokens to get new ones.
Conceptually, ID Token represents the 'Identity at time of login'. Often expires quickly (5-10 mins) or matches Access Token.
Ability of a system to switch crypto algorithms (e.g. RSA to ECDSA) easily if the current one is broken.
Attacker modifies JWT header to 'alg': 'none' and removes signature. Vulnerable libraries accept the unsigned token.
Attacker changes 'alg' to HS256 (HMAC) but signs with the Public Key (which is known). Server uses Public Key as HMAC secret.
IdP MUST exactly match the `redirect_uri` parameter against the registered whitelist. Loose matching (starts-with) causes Open Redirects.
If IdP redirects to ANY URL provided, attacker can craft link 'idp.com/login?redirect=evil.com'. User trusts IdP, lands on Evil.
If IdP inputs are not sanitized, XSS or SQLi in the Login Form could compromise the entire Identity Provider.
Attacker forces user to log in as the ATTACKER. User then saves sensitive data (credit card) into Attacker's account unknowingly.
Hosting IdP login page in a transparent iframe over a game. User clicks 'Shoot' but actually approves 'Consent'. Use X-Frame-Options: DENY.
Strict CSP prevents XSS on the Login Page. Prevents attackers from stealing credentials via injected JS keyloggers.
Header used to trace a request across microservices and IdP logs. Critical for debugging 'Why did login fail?'.
Sending IdP logs (Splunk/Sentinel) to detect patterns like Brute Force, Spraying, or Impossible Travel.
User logs in from New York at 9 AM, then London at 9:15 AM. Physically impossible. Flag as compromise.
Monitoring rate of logins. 100 failed attempts in 1 minute = Brute Force or Credential Stuffing.
Using username/password pairs stolen from Site A to try and login to Site B (because users reuse passwords). SSO mitigates this.
Mandated API access (PSD2). TPP (Third Party Provider) accesses Bank data with User Consent via OIDC/FAPI.
Healthcare standard profile of OAuth 2.0/OIDC. Allows health apps to securely access Electronic Health Records (EHR).
The standard behind 'Device Flow'. Designed for devices with limited input (no keyboard).
Client sends parameters (scope, redirect_uri) to IdP via backchannel POST first, gets a 'request_uri'. Browser uses that URI. Prevents URL tampering.
Hides authorization parameters from the Browser URL. Prevents PII leakage in logs and tampering in browser.
Sending the Authorization Parameters as a Signed JWT (Request Object) in the URL. Ensures integrity.
IdP returns the Authorization Response (Code/Token) inside a Signed JWT. Protects response from tampering.
Limiting how many hops a federation can go (A trusts B trusts C). Too many hops = loss of trust/context.
Details about user are temporary. Used for 'anonymous' sessions or one-time access where user Identity shouldn't persist.
Specific ID that persists across sessions for the same user. Used for linking account data.
Routing a user to the SAME IdP server node for duration of login flow. Needed if IdP stores state in RAM.
Storing IdP sessions in Redis/Memcached/DB so any node can handle the request. Eliminates need for Sticky Sessions.
Transforming attributes from IdP (e.g. 'department') to what App expects (e.g. 'role'). Done in IdP or Broker.
Rare. Usually Apps don't delete on login failure. Requires SCIM or Expiry logic.
When 'Roles' become too granular (User, Admin, Editor, Viewer for Project A, B, C...). Tokens become huge.
When a user is in 1000 groups, the ID Token/Kerberos Ticket exceeds header limits (HTTP 431). Login fails.
Technique to reduce token size (e.g. sending Group Ids instead of Names, or using a 'has_groups' endpoint).
Claim array showing HOW user authenticated (['pwd', 'mfa', 'fido']). Critical for 'Step-up' logic.
Both are IDaaS (Identity as a Service). Verify user identity and issue tokens. Competitors (now merged).
Popular Open Source Identity and Access Management solution. Supports SAML, OIDC, Social Login.
Cloud-native OIDC provider (often used with Kubernetes). Acts as a shim between App and upstream LDAP/SAML.
SAML 2.0 is the current standard. 1.0 and 1.1 are obsolete.
Legacy signature-based protocol. Complex. Replaced by OAuth 2.0 (Bearer Tokens + TLS).
Whoever holds the token can use it. Like cash. Theft = Access. Hence TLS and Short Lifetimes are vital.
Enhancement where presenter must PROVE they hold the private key associated with the ticket. Old SAML concept, reborn in DPoP/MTLS.
Prevents JS on site A from reading data from site B. SSO relies on redirects/CORS to bridge this.
Safe way for cross-origin iframes (App and IdP) to communicate (e.g. for silent token renewal).
User clicks link to 'App/Page1'. Redirects to Login. After Login, MUST redirect back to 'App/Page1'. Handled by RelayState/State.
SP stores the target URL in RelayState before sending user to IdP.
IdP sends RelayState with the Assertion, telling SP where to land the user.
Colloquial term for vendors charging extra (Enterprise Tier) just to enable SSO/SAML features.
Employees signing up for apps (Dropbox/Trello) with corp email but WITHOUT SSO. IT has no visibility/control.
Tool to discover Shadow IT and enforce policies (e.g. Block login to personal Gmail, allow Corp Gmail).
Network/Header control preventing users from logging into PERSONAL/Other tenants of an App (e.g. Office 365) from Corp Network.
Another name for Azure Managed Identity. Machine identity managed by Cloud Provider.
Identity for a Pod. Can exchange K8s Token for Cloud IAM Token (Workload Identity Federation) to access S3/SQL.
Action to obtain temporary credentials for a Role. Foundation of Cross-Account access and Federation.
Parameter used in AssumeRole to prevent 'Confused Deputy' problem when a 3rd party assumes a role in your account.
A Service (Deputy) is tricked into misusing its authority to perform an action for an attacker.
Message sent from SP to IdP (or vice versa) to initiate Single Logout.
id_token_hint (prove identity), post_logout_redirect_uri (where to go back).
Serverless functions running in the Auth Pipeline. Can modify tokens, call external APIs, or deny access.
Adding non-standard data to token (e.g. 'favorite_color'). Must be agreed upon by IdP and SP.
Protocol for exchanging one token (e.g. External ID Token) for another (Internal Access Token). Used in Gateways/Mesh.
Delegation: Acting ON BEHALF of user (User is present). Impersonation: Acting AS the user (User may not be present).
Microsoft specific extension (similar to Token Exchange) allowing API A to get a token for API B on behalf of User.
Token valid for multiple Resource Servers. 'aud': ['api1', 'api2']. risky if one resource is compromised.
Native Apps (Desktop) listen on http://127.0.0.1:port to receive the Auth Code from the System Browser.
Mobile Apps register 'com.app://callback' to capture redirects from System Browser. OS handles routing.
Modern replacement for Custom Schemes. Uses standard https:// URLs. OS verifies ownership via website file. More secure.
Timestamp when token was created. Used to calculate age.
Unique identifier for the JWT itself. Used to prevent replay (by tracking used IDs) or for revocation lists.
JWT content is encrypted (structure: header.encrypted_key.iv.ciphertext.tag). Hidden from client/intermediaries.
A Signed JWT inside an Encrypted JWT (Sign-then-Encrypt). Provenance + Privacy.
SHA-256 hash of the X.509 certificate. Stronger than x5t (SHA-1).

q: Why separate Auth Server and Resource Server?
o: Separation of Concerns. Auth Server specializes in Identity/Policy. Resource Server specializes in Business Logic.
Using a policy engine (OPA, XACML) to decide access centrally, rather than hardcoding logic in every microservice.
General-purpose policy engine. Uses Rego language. Frequently used for K8s admission and Microservice Authorization.
Legacy XML standard for ABAC (Attribute Based Access Control). Powerful but verbose and complex.
API vulnerability where User A can access User B's object (GET /invoice/123) by changing the ID. SSO doesn't fix this automatically.
User A can access Admin API (POST /admin/deleteUser) because the backend checks 'Is User Logged In?' but not 'Is User Admin?'.
Allowing users to create groups and invite others (e.g. 'Project X Team'). Self-service reduces IT burden.
Bundle of resources (SharePoint, App Role, Group) that users can request access to. Automatic expiry and approval workflows.
Using Short-lived SSH Certificates signed by a CA (linked to SSO Identity) instead of static SSH Keys.
Using Remote Credential Guard or Azure AD joined VMs to login with SSO credentials.
Secure server exposed to internet. Admins SSH/RDP to Bastion (with MFA), then jump to internal servers. Reduces attack surface.
Dedicated, hardened laptop used ONLY for Admin tasks. Never used for email/browsing. Prevents phishing/malware compromise of Admin Creds.
Tier 0 (Domain Controllers/Root), Tier 1 (Servers), Tier 2 (Workstations). Admins of T1 cannot login to T0. Prevents lateral movement.
Legacy Microsoft architecture. Separate Admin Forest trusted by Prod Forests. Replaced by Modern Access/Cloud Tiering.
Standard (RFC 7643/7644) for automating User Provisioning (Create, Update, Delete) between IdP and Apps.
JSON-based schema defining User and Group attributes (e.g. urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:core:2.0:User).
SCIM pushes updates (e.g. disable user) IMMEDIATELY. SAML JIT only updates when user LOGS IN. SCIM is better for security.
Umbrella term for WebAuthn (Browser API) and CTAP (Protocol for Security Keys). Enables Passwordless Auth.
Public Key Cryptography. Private key stays on device (TPM/YubiKey). Public key sent to Server.
Process where the authenticator proves its make/model to the server (e.g. 'I am a YubiKey 5 NFC').
Private Key stored persistently on the Authenticator. Allows 'Passwordless' login (User just inserts key, no username needed).
Bit in WebAuthn response proving user touched the device (intent). Prevents malware from using connected key silently.
Bit proving user authenticated to the device (PIN or Biometric). Higher security than simple touch.
Multi-device FIDO credentials. Synced across user's devices (iCloud Keychain, Google Password Manager). Usable vs device-bound.
Key that CANNOT leave the hardware (TPM/YubiKey). Higher security (anti-cloning) but risk of lockout if lost.
NIST SP 800-63 standard. AAL1 (Password), AAL2 (MFA), AAL3 (Hardware Crypto MFA).
Confidence in WHO the user is (Proofing). IAL1 (Self-asserted), IAL2 (Remote Proofing), IAL3 (In-person Proofing).
Confidence in the Federation assertion. FAL1 (Bearer), FAL2 (Encrypted), FAL3 (Holder-of-Key).
Older term (ISO 29115) replaced by NIST's IAL/AAL/FAL split. Rough measure of trust in identity.
Intermediary that bridges trust between disparate IdPs (e.g. Universities) and SPs. e.g. EduGain, InCommon.
Process of determining WHICH IdP a user belongs to (e.g. by entering email domain first).
SP sends a hint (e.g. domain=company.com) to the Federation Hub to skip the HRD screen and go straight to Corp IdP.
Attacker spams user with Push Notifications until they get annoyed and click 'Approve'. Countermeasure: Number Matching.
User must type a number displayed on the PC screen INTO the Authenticator App. Proves proximity and intent.
If User=Admin AND Location=Foreign AND Device=Unknown -> BLOCK. Dynamic rules evaluated at login.
IdP notifies SP (via SSE/RISC) to revoke access IMMEDIATELY if conditions change (e.g. User disabled) during the session.
User is logged in (Low assurance), tries to access 'High Value Data'. App triggers interactive auth (MFA) to upgrade assurance.
System calculates risk score (Device, IP, Time). If Risk > Threshold, challenge with MFA. Else allow silent login.
Emergency Admin account excluded from MFA/SSO/CondAccess policies. Used if IdP goes down or configuration locks everyone out.
Attacker steals the IdP's Token Signing Key (Private Key). Can forge ANY SAML assertion for ANY user to ANY app. Ultimate compromise.
Attacker steals a valid TGT (Ticket Granting Ticket) from memory (lsass.exe). Uses it to request Service Tickets without password.
Cloud equivalent of Pass-the-Ticket. Stealing the Azure AD PRT to gain persistent SSO access to cloud resources.
Forged Service Ticket encrypted with the SERVICE'S password hash. Gives access to that one service only.
Forged TGT encrypted with the KRBTGT password hash. Gives Domain Admin access to EVERYTHING.
Malware patches LSASS on Domain Controller to accept a 'master password' for ANY account, while original password still works.
Attacker registers a rouge Domain Controller. Pushes malicious changes (e.g. SID history) via replication, bypassing logging.
Attacker pretends to be a DC and asks for password hashes (replication). Needs 'Replicate Directory Changes' permission.
AD object that templates permissions for Protected Groups (Admins). Attackers modify it to gain persistence (re-add themselves).
Adding the SID of an Admin group (from another domain) to a standard user's SID History attribute. Granting Admin rights.
Limiting which services a specific account can delegate credentials TO. Safer than Unconstrained Delegation.
Delegation rule configured on the RESOURCE object (who can trust me), not the Account. Allows cross-domain delegation.
Unique identifier for a service instance in Kerberos. Clients request tickets for specific SPNs (e.g. HTTP/web.corp.com).
Requesting a Service Ticket for an SPN, then cracking the ticket offline to recover the Service Account's plaintext password.
Targeting users with 'Do not require Pre-Authentication'. Request TGT, crack the encrypted part to get user password.
AD accounts with auto-managed 120-char complex passwords. Immune to Kerberoasting (usually) and password theft.
Restricting where high-privilege accounts can logon (e.g. Domain Admins can only logon to DCs).
Tool to sync On-Prem AD users/hashes to Azure AD (Hybrid Identity).
Syncing a hash of the password hash to the cloud. Allows users to sign in to Cloud apps with same password.
Cloud IdP validates password by calling an On-Prem Agent. Password never technically leaves on-prem AD validation logic.
Microsoft's On-Prem IdP/STS. Provides SAML/OIDC for internal AD users to External Apps.
In AD FS, trusting an upstream IdP (e.g. Partner Company) to authenticate users.
In AD FS, defining an Application that trusts AD FS. Equivalent to 'Client Registration' or 'SP Configuration'.
Backchannel service to exchange a small reference (Artifact) for the full SAML Assertion. Used when Assertion is too big for Browser URL.
SP asking IdP for more user attributes AFTER the initial login. Rare in modern web SSO.
Susceptible to Login CSRF/Session Fixation if not handled carefuly. Also lacks 'InResponseTo' field in assertion.
Another name for IdP-Initiated SSO. IdP sends assertion without SP asking first.
Time difference between IdP and SP clocks. Tokens MUST allow a small window (e.g. 5 mins) to account for this.
Time validity conditions in SAML/JWT. SP MUST check these to prevent replay of old tokens.
XML element in SAML binding the assertion to a context (RequestID, Recipient URL, IP). Critical security check.
Reference determining strictly HOW the user authenticated (e.g. 'urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:ac:classes:PasswordProtectedTransport').
Standard (RFC 8485) to express complex assurance requirements (Identity + MFA + Device) in a single value.
Token contains a REFERENCE to where claims can be fetched (endpoint + token), rather than the claims themselves. Reduces token size.
Different User ID for each App (SP). Prevents apps from colluding to track user behavior across the ecosystem.
Grouping mechanism for Pairwise IDs. Apps in same group (e.g. 'Google Maps' and 'Google Drive') see same User ID.

q: Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) enforcement?
o: OAuth 2.1 mandates PKCE for ALL clients (Public and Confidential). Preventing code injection.
Authenticating Client via Client Certificate during token request. Also binds token to that certificate (Sender Constrained).
Application-layer mechanism to bind tokens to a private key held by the client. Alternative to mTLS.
Works better in environments where TLS is terminated by Load Balancers/CDNs that strip certificates.
Legacy OAuth grant where App handles User/Password directly. DEPRECATED/REMOVED in OAuth 2.1. Insecure.
Legacy OAuth grant returning tokens in URL fragment. Vulnerable to leakage. DEPRECATED in favor of Auth Code + PKCE.
High-security profile of OIDC/OAuth for Fintech. Mandates mTLS/DPoP, PAR, JAR, and strict crypto.
Don't roll your own crypto, don't roll your own Auth. Use standard libraries.
